image.altText: A woman sits in the passenger seat of a car, looking to one side with a serious expression. The windows have rain drops on them.

props.synopsis: People living with disabilities are being coerced into rented accommodation by unscrupulous operators who can drain their NDIS funding and leave them with little, if any, support.

title.children: This nurse has had to rescue clients 'abducted' by unscrupulous NDIS providers

image.altText: Tasha Jordan and Ken Belbin standing next to the Golden Homes sign.

props.synopsis: Two families who sank their life savings into building their dream homes are unable to move in, with one family left living in a shed and the other couch-surfing.

title.children: 'An interesting form of construction!': Surveyors tell Tasha her home is not built to code, but no-one will fix it

image.altText: Composite image Steve Fisher 2003 and 2023

props.synopsis: Twenty years ago, Steve Fisher became the first person in Tasmania to win the legal right to identify himself as a victim-survivor of child sexual abuse. Now, with a groundbreaking report to be handed down this week, he says the reckoning has only just begun.

title.children: 'I'm a victim of Garth Hawkins': 20 years ago, Steve had to fight in court to identify himself

image.altText: Samu Kerevi holds his face

props.synopsis: The Wallabies fall to a record-breaking Rugby World Cup defeat against Wales, falling into old traps and making crucial errors of judgement. Here are the five key moments from an embarrassing defeat in Lyon.

title.children: Five quick hits — An opening-minute blunder and a final-minute fan exodus as Wallabies hit World Cup low

image.altText: Two men in wetsuits fist pump the air with glee at the beach

props.synopsis: When Aussie rock band Silverchair broke up in 2011, drummer Ben Gillies was left feeling sad, heavy and unsure where to turn. Then he had a frightening anxiety attack while in the surf. This is how he staged a life comeback.

title.children: Silverchair drummer Ben Gillies reveals the ultimatum that would change his life after the band collapsed

image.altText: A dark-grey capsule with a yellow port sits on the ground in the desert.

props.synopsis: A NASA space capsule carrying the largest soil samples ever scooped up from the surface of an asteroid streaks through Earth's atmosphere and parachutes into the Utah desert.

title.children: 'Really historic' asteroid sample returned to Earth as NASA eyes the future

image.altText: Mike Pezzullo holds his hands in the air as he sits at a desk inside a Parliament House committee room

props.synopsis: The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age have published text messages sent over a number of years between Mike Pezzullo and Scott Briggs, an influential figure within the Liberal Party.

title.children: Home Affairs boss Mike Pezzullo referred to public service commissioner over texts to Liberal Party powerbroker

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

props.synopsis: The federal government will release its employment white paper after a year-long consultation that will pave the way for future jobs and skills in Australia, while the ASX has opened lower after Wall Street fell on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: 'Very important day' as government releases employment white paper, US government shutdown looms, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian sharemarket has opened lower on Monday, down 0.5% to 7,033 points at 10:30am AEST. (For live market figures at any time, head to the top of the blog.) Most of the sectors are in the red so far, with industrials down 1.3%, followed by academic and educational services (-1.1%) and real estate (-1%). Financials and basic materials are down 0.7% each. Utilities is the only sector in positive territory with a slight gain of 0.1%, while energy is flat. Qantas meanwhile has slipped by 2.2% after disclosing that it's spending another $80 million on customer improvements and forecasts a $ 200 million addition to its fuel costs. The top five performers so far: Paladin Energy +4.6% Whitehaven Coal +3.1% New Hope Corporation +2.4% Coronado Global Resources +1.7% Altium +1.7% The bottom five performers: Allkem -4.2% Atlas Ateria -3.9% Bellevue Gold -3.7% Genesis Minerals -3.6% Capricorn Metals -3.5%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as miners and financials in the red, Qantas down on fuel costs

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas also used its statement to the ASX this morning to note that new aircraft deliveries and wet-leasing agreements will help Qantas and Jetstar increase its international flight capacity by the end of the year. The airline says the arrangements will see its international capacity increase by 12 percentage points by December 31 — equivalent to almost 50 flights a week. "This includes Qantas resuming its Sydney-Shanghai services and starting two new routes, Brisbane-Wellington and Brisbane-Honiara, as well as a new Jetstar service from Brisbane to Tokyo ," the company said in a statement. Qantas also notes that demand for travel right now remains strong, and expects to carry more than 4 million passengers during the September/October school holidays and football finals, with 35,000 domestic and international services. Compared to this time last year, Qantas had 3.7 million passengers on around 28,000 services over those four weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: International flights to increase by almost 50 a week by the end of year, Qantas says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has also flagged its fuel bill for the current financial year will top $2.8 billion — $200 million more than it had budgeted for off the back of higher prices. The airline says the combination of higher oil prices, higher refiner margins and a weaker Australian dollar are responsible for the substantial rise in its fuel costs. Qantas says it intends to absorb the higher costs for now, but will monitor fuel prices in the coming weeks. "If current levels are sustained, [Qantas] will look to adjust its settings ," the airline said in a statement to the ASX. "Any changes would look to balance the recovery of higher costs with the importance of affordable travel in an environment where fares are already elevated ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas facing $200m increase to fuel bill as prices surge

image.altText: Chinese tourists posing to camera in the Blue Mountains.

props.synopsis: From today, the Australian government will restart the visa process for Chinese group travellers in what is expected to be a major boost to Australian tourism.

title.children: Chinese visitors to reach pre-pandemic levels by year's end as federal government allows group travel to resume

image.altText: A drone shot shows suburban blocks in South Auckland.

props.synopsis: In Auckland, the council has been running an experiment, and at the heart of it is a bold decision to remove restrictions around zoning — but the New Zealand election could change things.

title.children: Australia has long debated this housing idea, but in Auckland it's already working

image.altText: Usher, wearing sunglasses and a light pink jacket and pants, smiles as he sings into a microphone on stage.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Usher to headline the 2024 Super Bowl half-time show in Las Vegas. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Northern Territory chief minister says she welcomes tough conversations with the public but reverting to violence is never acceptable. Natasha Fyles was attacked yesterday at the Nightcliff Markets in Darwin after a woman shoved a plate of crepes in her face. A 56-year-old woman is set to appear in Darwin Local Court next month on charges of aggravated assault in relation to the incident. Speaking to Katie Wolfe on Mix FM, Fyles says accessibility to politicians is important but violence is not okay. "I don't necessarily expect everyone to agree with me, I don't want them to agree with me, part of democracy is being able to have that robust debate," she said. "And that's what it should be, a debate, not a whack in the face." If you missed yesterday's story, you can catch up below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'A debate, not a whack in the face': NT Chief Minister says violence is never acceptable

featuredLink.title: 'Disgusting': Police charge woman after NT chief minister allegedly attacked with pancake

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is busy preparing to release the federal government's new employment strategy at midday. But when speaking to Sabra Lane on AM, the Treasurer was also asked about the secretary of the Home Affairs Department, Mike Pezzullo, being referred to the Australian Public Service Commissioner over text messages sent to a Liberal Party powerbroker. Lane : "How comfortable are you with that behaviour from a senior public servant?" Chalmers : "Well, first of all, I only saw those stories last night and as I understand it, Minister Clare O'Neil has referred these issues to the Public Service Commissioner. He will advise her on this matter, and in advance of that… you know, I'm reluctant to get into it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jim Chalmers 'reluctant' to comment on Mike Pezzullo texts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Taylor Swift is in her American football era. The 12-time Grammy Award winner accepted Travis Kelce 's invitation to see the Kansas City Chiefs play the Chicago Bears at Arrowhead Stadium. Rumours have been flying recently that the global pop superstar and footballer have been seeing each other. It all began when Kelce said on his New Heights podcast that he was disappointed that he didn't have the chance to meet Swift and gift her a friendship bracelet during her stop in Kansas City on her Eras Tour. Then, during an appearance on The Pat McAfee Show, Kelce said: "I threw the ball in her court and told her, 'I've seen you rock the stage in Arrowhead. You might have to come see me rock the stage in Arrowhead and see which one's a little more lit.'" Swift is currently on a break from her sold-out Eras world tour, which resumes in November.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Taylor Swift turns out to see Travis Kelce, Kansas City Chiefs play Chicago Bears
